child.pub-comments: The affiliation of Kru and Ijo to the Kwa group is to be considered tentative. Kwa and Benue-Congo are particularly close to each other and in fact legitmate doubts arise concerning the validity of the division between them. On the other hand West Atlantic seems more remotely related to the other group and Mande the most distant of all. These opinions coincide to a considerable degree with those of W. E. Welmers (personal communications) and receive some support from unpublished glottochronological data of R. Wescott. (p. 39)

The subgrouping of Mande given here is in substantial agreement with that of W. W. Welmers in "The Mande Languages" (Report of the 11th Annual Round Table Meeting on Linguistics and Language Studies, pp. 8-21, Washington, 1961). The incorrectness of the traditional division into Mande-tan and Mande-fu is likewise reckognized by A. Prost in Les Langue Mande-Sud du groupe Mana-Busa (Dakar, 1953). (pp. 39-40)

child.pub-comments: The languages listed here from Avatime to Anyimere inclusive are the so-called 'Togo remnant languages." They belong integrally within this subgroup of Kwa.

child.pub-comments: p. 37 "In the present work, absence of mention in the list of Benue-Congo languages of a border languages is tacit evidence of my opinion that it is Bantu." p. 41 "The languages listed under numbers 227, 228, 230, 232, 233, 234 ,235, 236, 237 and 253 as Semi-Bantu in Johnston's classic work, 'The Bantu and Semi-Bantu Languages', are considered here to be Bantu."

child.pub-comments: "This is not to be confused with a Chadic language likewise called Masa in the same area. I have referred to the latter by an alternate name Bana (unfortunately also employed for the Niger-Congo language mentioned here)." p. 40

child.pub-comments: "Those languages of the Nuba hills of Kordofan which have not already been assigned to various subgroups of the Eastern Sudanic subdivision of the Chari-Nile family (i.e. Dagu, Temein and Nubian) form a single Kordofanian family. These languages fall into five clearly distinguishable subgroups of which the fourth (Tumtum) shows considerable divergence from the remainder. The languages of the Kordofanian family are as follows:" (p. 149)
